# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is an example of how you can solve this problem in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter the dataframe for rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_new = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Add a new column that is true for all rows of the filtered dataframe
    df_new[:audi_a4_type] = [true for _ in 1:nrow(df_new)]
    
    return df_new
end
```
This function `audi_filter` uses the `filter` function from the DataFrames package to filter out rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then creates a new column called `audi_a4_type`, which is true for all of these filtered rows.

You can use this function like so:
```julia
df = DataFrame(manufacturer=[string(i) for i in 1:10], model=["a3" "a4" "a4 quattro" "a5" "a6" "a7" "a8" "a9" "a10"])
df_new = audi_filter(df)
```
`df_new` will now be a new DataFrame that includes only the rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro", along with an extra column `audi_a4_type` which is true for all of these rows.
